_meta.note: Deep lore for Dice Dungeon world. Never stated directly - only hinted through flavor text, items, and environmental details.

world_concept.the_probability_engine: An ancient mechanism beneath reality that calculated fate itself using crystallized chance
world_concept.the_fall: When the Engine's keepers vanished, its dice scattered into reality, granting mortals power over probability
world_concept.the_dungeon: Not built by hands - the floors are failed probability calculations, crystallized timelines that never came to pass
world_concept.the_descent: Each floor deeper shows older, stranger attempts at reality. Floor 100 is where probability itself was born
world_concept.dice_magic: Dice are fragments of the Engine. Rolling them doesn't decide fate - it calculates which fate is already happening
world_concept.the_keepers: They called themselves the Calculators. Some say they became their equations. Others say they're still here, watching

starting_area.name: The Threshold Chamber
starting_area.description: A circular stone chamber with impossibly smooth walls. Ancient symbols glow faintly on every surface. The air hums with potential.
lore_hints: The walls show equations in languages that predate writing
Torch flames here burn in perfect geometric patterns
Your footsteps echo strangely, multiplying in number
The door ahead is marked with a single glowing die

signs.title: Stone Tablet - The First Law
signs.text:
WHAT WAS ROLLED CANNOT BE UNROLLED

Some say the Calculators wrote this. Others say it wrote them. The distinction may not matter.

[Worn inscription below:] '...many faces, infinite outcomes... Engine demands tribute... deeper = older = truer...'

signs.title: Crumbling Scroll - Fragment
signs.text:
Day ??? of the Descent:

We found it. The calculation that made everything. It's still running.

It wants us to check its work.

The dice aren't tools. They're QUESTIONS.

[The rest is too damaged to read]

signs.title: Warning Plaque
signs.text:
DELVERS' NOTICE

The dungeon rearranges. Always has. Each floor is a different answer to the same question.

Q: What could have been?
A: Keep rolling.

We think the original Calculators made it to Floor 87. Their last notes spoke of 'probability collapsing into truth' and 'meeting our own equations.'

Nobody's seen them since.

- Delvers' Guild, Year of the Eclipse

signs.title: Brass Plaque - Rules
signs.text:
THE DUNGEON'S TERMS:

• Each floor is one iteration deeper
• Dice determine what is, not what might be
• What you find was always going to be found
• The stairs only appear when probability allows
• Items are echoes of decisions never made

You cannot die here.
You can only stop calculating.

[Below in smaller text:]
'If you see yourself, don't roll. Just run.'

starter_chests.description: A small wooden chest with geometric carvings. It's warm to the touch.
starter_chests.lore: Someone left this for you. Or maybe you left it for yourself on another timeline.

starter_chests.description: A stone coffer sealed with wax. The wax shows strange handprints.
starter_chests.lore: The Calculators left marks wherever they went. Some say their hands had too many fingers. Others say too few.

ambient_details: The walls pulse very slightly, like a heartbeat, but the rhythm is mathematical
Shadows here don't quite match the light sources
If you stare at the floor patterns long enough, you swear they're... counting
Something ticks. Not regularly. It ticks in prime numbers.

dice_quotes: The die remembers every roll it never made
The dice are older than they look
Your dice feel heavier after you roll them, as if weighted by outcomes
The dice click together and for a moment you hear... whispering?
Sometimes the dice land before you finish throwing them
floor_transition: The stairs descend into deeper probability
You descend another layer into what-never-was
The Engine's pulse grows louder as you descend
This floor smells of dust and unfinished calculations
item_implications: Items here aren't created. They're remembered into existence.
Every item has a story. Most of those stories haven't happened yet.
The hourglass shards - remnants of when time was still being decided
Lucky Chips: probability crystallized into solid form
